Fig. 3 ML guidance flowchart. Fig. 4 Research publication trend on (a) HER catalyst development method including (i) HER catalyst experimental synthesis, (ii) DFT in HER catalyst synthesis, (iii) DFT and ML in HER catalyst synthesis. (b) The number of journal articles associated with ML in HER catalyst synthesis (i) thermochemical, (ii) electrocatalyst, (iii) photocatalyst or photoelectrode, and (iv) biocatalyst/bioelectrodes-based catalyst. Data were acquired from Scopus.com [100]. Fig. 5 Data-driven electrocatalyst development using a hybrid ML and DFT approach: (a) A DNN for predicting elements in crystallographic sites. It includes input and output layers, with various activation functions for different layers. Dropout is applied between layers, except for the output layers. Reproduced with permission from Ref. [124]. Copyright 2018, American Chemical Society. Developing data-driven descriptors and enhanced scaling relations to predict the reactivity of transition metal oxides: (b) side views of oxygen-rich terminations on low-index facets of rutile-structured oxides: green represents transition metal (TM) atoms (Ru or Ir); while red represents oxygen (O) atoms. The positions considered for substitutional doping are marked: (c) adsorption enthalpies of OOH* versus OH* from our DFT database: solid lines denote universal scaling relations, while the dashed line represents ideal scaling; and (d) the theoretical overpotential (ƞ the) in a negative direction for all materials in their database as a function of O* adsorption enthalpy. Reproduced with permission from Ref. [128]. Copyright 2020, American Chemical Society. Fig. 6 Data-driven electrocatalyst development using a hybrid ML and DFT approach: A systematic approach for discovering high-performance catalysts for the HER using 2D MXene. It integrates rapid computing and the Sabatier principle to identify efficient HER catalysts. ML creates descriptors that capture the alloying effect in HER catalysts. Additionally, the study identifies relationships between adsorption and electronic structures through solid band and molecular orbital theories. Reproduced with permission from Ref. [136]. Glossary Explanation Density-based spatial clustering of applications with noise (DBSCAN) A density-based clustering algorithm that groups together data points in dense regions and identifies noise points as outliers. Decision tree A supervised learning algorithm that builds a tree-like model to make predictions by splitting the data based on feature values Gradient boosting tree (GBT) GBT is an ML tool that combines several weak predictions (like small, simple decision trees) to make firm predictions. It corrects mistakes made by previous predictions and improves with each step. Hierarchical clustering A clustering algorithm that builds a hierarchy of clusters by recursively merging or splitting them based on their similarity. Kernel support vector machine (SVM) An extension of linear SVM that uses a kernel function to map the data into a higher-dimensional feature space. It is effective for handling non-linearly separable data. k-means Clustering algorithms partition data into k clusters based on their similarity. k-means are suitable for continuous data, while k-modes are used for categorical data. Linear regression A supervised learning algorithm models the relationship between a dependent variable and one or more independent variables. It assumes a linear relationship between the variables. Linear support vector classification (SVC) A binary classification technique that separates two classes by finding the optimal hyperplane and maximizing the margin between the classes for better generalization. It is fast and interpretable, suitable for linearly separable data. Logistic regression A supervised learning algorithm used for binary classification problems. It predicts the probability of an event occurring based on a set of independent variables. Manifold learning An unsupervised ML technique for reducing dimensionality. It assumes that high-dimensional data lies on a lower-dimensional manifold within the higher-dimensional space. Neural network A network of interconnected nodes (neurons) inspired by the human brain, it learns from data to perform tasks such as classification, regression, and pattern recognition. Principal component analysis (PCA) A dimensionality reduction technique that transforms high-dimensional data into a lower-dimensional space while preserving its most important features Random forest (RF) An ensemble learning method that builds multiple decision trees and combines their predictions to improve accuracy and reduce overfitting. Graphical abstract Challenges and opportunities of machine learning in hydrogen production, addressing issues such as data scarcity, interpretability, safety, integration, privacy, and scalability with potential solutions and future directions. With the projected global surge in hydrogen demand, driven by increasing applications and the imperative for low-emission hydrogen, the integration of machine learning (ML) across the hydrogen energy value chain is a compelling avenue. This review uniquely focuses on harnessing the synergy between ML and computational modeling (CM) or optimization tools, as well as integrating multiple ML techniques with CM, for the synthesis of diverse hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) catalysts and various hydrogen production processes (HPPs). Furthermore, this review addresses a notable gap in the literature by offering insights, analyzing challenges, and identifying research prospects and opportunities for sustainable hydrogen production. While the literature reflects a promising landscape for ML applications in hydrogen energy domains, transitioning AI-based algorithms from controlled environments to real-world applications poses significant challenges. Hence, this comprehensive review delves into the technical, practical, and ethical considerations associated with the application of ML in HER catalyst development and HPP optimization. Overall, this review provides guidance for unlocking the transformative potential of ML in enhancing prediction efficiency and sustainability in the hydrogen production sector. Keywords Machine learning Computational modeling HER catalyst synthesis Hydrogen energy, Hydrogen production processes Algorithm development 1 Introduction The global reliance on fossil fuels has led to environmental concerns and record-high CO2 emissions in 2021 (i.e., 36.3 billion tons) [1], necessitating a shift towards renewable energy sources, projected to meet over 50% of global energy needs by 2040. Hydrogen, as a versatile energy carrier, holds promise for effectively harnessing renewables and decarbonizing sectors to achieve net-zero CO2 emissions by 2050 [2]. Additionally, existing infrastructure can be repurposed for hydrogen storage and transportation, utilizing various renewable energy sources to produce clean hydrogen [3]. Global hydrogen consumption has increased by 3% since 2013, with notable surges in major regions except Europe (Fig. 1 a and b) [4]. North America and the Middle East grew strongly, while China remained the largest consumer. However, adoption in emerging clean energy sectors remained minimal. The Global Hydrogen Report 2023 indicates that this growth reflects broader energy trends with limited climate change mitigation [4]. Forecasts suggest a 6% annual hydrogen growth until 2030, surpassing 150 million metric tons, largely driven by new applications. In contrast, global hydrogen production reached nearly 95 million metric tons in 2022, dominated by fossil fuels. Low-emission production, primarily from fossil fuels with carbon capture, utilization, and storage (CCUS), remained minimal below 1 million metric tons (Fig. 1c) [5]. China accounted for almost 30% of global production, with over 70% concentrated in China, the United States, the Middle East, India, and Russia. Ongoing low-emission hydrogen projects could exceed 20 million metric tons annually by 2030, mainly driven by electrolysis [4]. Ongoing low-emission projects, driven by electrolysis, are expected to exceed 20 million metric tons annually by 2030, with Europe and Australia leading in electrolytic initiatives [4]. Despite progress, a significant gap remains, particularly in electrolysis and fossil fuel-based production with carbon capture, to align with Net Zero Emissions by 2050 goals. The projected increase in global hydrogen demand and production underscores the necessity to apply computational modeling throughout the hydrogen value chain, particularly in hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) catalyst development and optimizing hydrogen production processes (HPP) and systems. Computational modeling, such as density functional theory (DFT), plays a pivotal role in boosting hydrogen production through catalyst development by providing insights into catalyst mechanisms [6], optimizing catalysts [7], analyzing reaction pathways [8], predictive modeling [9], and aiding in catalyst design [10]. These findings demonstrate the significant impact of DFT in advancing the development of efficient catalysts for hydrogen production. Computational modeling can also optimize HPP by identifying bottlenecks [11], predicting temperature distributions in reformer tubes [12], and improving supply chain efficiency [13]. It assesses the environmental impacts of different HPPs [14], facilitates debottlenecking in chemical plants [15], and designs demand response schemes for electrolysis-based production [16], enhancing efficiency, sustainability, and industrial decarbonization. Despite the advantages of conventional computational modeling, DFT faces limitations in predicting HER activity. For instance, the stability of catalysts is crucial, with metallicity being more influential than structure or composition, complicating improvements without compromising stability [17]. DFT also struggles to accurately predict reaction mechanisms and HER activity on supported catalysts due to interactions like van der Waals forces [18]. Conventional computational modeling in HPP is also an inevitable challenge. These include accounting for external factors like electricity prices and renewable energy sources [16], adapting thermochemical reaction models to low temperatures [19], and optimizing energy and exergy efficiencies [20]. Additionally, modeling complexities such as reaction kinetics, spatial distribution of variables [21], and the computational intensity of traditional models hinders accurate simulations [21]. Current models also struggle with unreasonable unit designs and lack predictive capabilities [22], necessitating advanced modeling techniques and improved predictive algorithms. Integrating ML with computational modeling significantly enhances the development of HER catalysts and HPP. In HER catalyst development, ML accelerates and refines the screening process [23,24], increases prediction accuracy, and reduces computational costs [24,25], leading to the discovery of efficient, earth-abundant catalysts [24,26]. In HPP, ML optimizes energy utilization [27,28], improves yield predictions [28], and enables precise state predictions through complex relationship modeling [29]. These advancements lead to more efficient, accurate, and sustainable hydrogen production. Multiple ML approaches, such as hybrid algorithms and advanced models, further amplify these benefits by combining ML with analytical techniques and response surface methodology [30]. The hybrid strategy accelerates design space exploration through frameworks like Bayesian active learning [31], leading to more efficient hydrogen production in less time. These advantages collectively result in more effective and sustainable hydrogen production solutions. Despite numerous recent reviews on the application of ML in hydrogen production, a comprehensive analysis of its integration with computational modeling techniques and the application of multiple MLs approaches for developing diverse HER catalysts and optimizing various HPP methods remains undocumented. This review uniquely encompasses the synthesis of various HER catalysts (thermochemical based-catalyst, electrocatalysts, photocatalysts, and biocatalysts/bioelectrode) and diverse HPP techniques (thermochemical, electrical, photonic, biochemical, and chemical) via ML approaches. Table 1 assesses the scopes and gaps in existing reviews. This review seeks to bridge this gap by exploring the challenges and emerging opportunities associated with employing MLs and their integration with conventional computational modeling. Additionally, by addressing technical, practical, and ethical considerations of ML in HPP, the present review outlines research prospects that go beyond mere algorithm development. 2 Concept and guidelines of machine learning (ML) In recent years, the use of ML has increased significantly across numerous industries. ML involves the development of computational models of learning inspired by various disciplines, such as cognitive sciences, computer science, and statistics [39]. It allows machines to automatically learn and improve their performance based on experience, often without the need for explicit programming [40,41]. Explicit programming is the traditional method where a developer writes detailed instructions for the computer to perform a specific task. Its primary goal is to develop algorithms that can autonomously acquire knowledge from data, facilitating the identification of trends and forecasting prospective outcomes [34]. There are mainly three techniques within the field of ML. These techniques include (i) supervised learning, (ii) unsupervised learning, and (iii) reinforcement learning, each serving distinct purposes in acquiring knowledge and recognizing patterns. Supervised learning relies on a teacher (human supervision) providing labels for data samples, constituting human supervision [42]. It encompasses strong supervision with fully ground-truth labels as well as weak supervision with incomplete, inexact, or inaccurate labels [43]. In the hydrogen-based energy sector, supervised learning is proposed to include training an AI model using labeled samples to predict the efficiency of hydrogen fuel cells based on input parameters [44,45]. The model learns patterns and relationships by analyzing a dataset containing labeled examples of fuel cell configurations and their corresponding efficiencies to estimate the efficiency of new, unlabeled fuel cells accurately. This method enables researchers, engineers, and energy providers to optimize fuel cell designs, improve energy conversion efficiency, and advance the adoption of hydrogen as a clean energy source. Unsupervised learning in the hydrogen-based energy sector is suggested to discover hidden patterns and structures in data without explicit labels or guidance using an AI model [46,47]. By analyzing hydrogen production data, the unsupervised learning algorithm identifies clusters, relationships, or patterns that may not be initially apparent. These insights can be utilized to optimize HPP, improve efficiency, and guide decision-making for more effective and sustainable hydrogen production in areas such as process parameter tuning and optimization strategies. Reinforcement learning in the hydrogen-based energy sector has the potential to make decisions that maximize rewards in an environment involving an AI agent [48,49]. For example, in optimizing hydrogen storage in a renewable energy system, the agent observes factors like renewable energy generation and hydrogen storage level and takes actions such as adjusting the flow of electricity to the hydrogen electrolyzer or releasing stored hydrogen. By receiving rewards based on its actions, the agent learns to associate certain states with higher rewards and refines its strategy over time. This reinforcement learning process leads to the agent making optimal decisions that balance renewable energy utilization and hydrogen reserves, ultimately enhancing the efficiency and performance of the hydrogen-based energy system. Solving an ML problem involves a structured workflow as illustrated in the provided flowchart (Fig. 2 ). The process begins with clearly defining the problem, which guides the selection of relevant data sources from databases, literature reviews, experimental setups, and IoT devices. The gathered data undergoes pre-processing, including variable screening, data cleaning, handling missing values, and normalization to ensure quality and consistency. The data are then split into training and test sets to facilitate model evaluation. Selecting an appropriate ML model, such as artificial neural networks (ANN), support vector machines (SVM), or random forests (RF), depends on the problem's nature and data characteristics. The model is trained using the training set, with data visualization helping to track performance metrics like R 2, RMSE, MSE, and MAE. Evaluating the model on the test set assesses its generalizability. If necessary, hyperparameter tuning is performed to optimize performance, and hybrid models may be considered for better prediction accuracy. The finalized model is deployed into production and undergoing continuous monitoring and updates to address evolving issues. This systematic approach ensures the development of a robust, accurate, and scalable ML model that effectively addresses the defined problem. When selecting an ML algorithm, it is vital to consider factors like accuracy, training time, and implementation simplicity [50]. While accuracy is often prioritized, beginners tend to choose familiar algorithms. Initially, ease of implementation and quick results are favored, but investing time in more sophisticated algorithms can improve data understanding and results. However, the most effective algorithms may not have the highest reported accuracy, requiring meticulous fine-tuning and training. It is important to understand that the guidelines are general recommendations, allowing for variations. Exploring a comprehensive range of options and experimentation is the definitive method for finding the most suitable algorithm. A guidance flowchart for selecting the ML algorithm is proposed in Fig. 3 , and a glossary table is provided to aid in understanding of the flowchart (Table 2 ). Dimension reduction in ML simplifies models, reduces computation time, and can enhance performance by minimizing input variables [51]. Two main techniques are proposed: Principal component analysis (PCA) and manifold learning [51–53]. PCA is a linear technique that reduces dimensionality by transforming data into principal components that capture the most variance, suitable for linear data structures [52]. Manifold learning, a nonlinear technique, is used when data is complex and lies on a manifold, making it ideal for nonlinear data [53]. To choose between PCA and manifold learning, analyze the data's linearity; use PCA for linear relationships and manifold learning techniques like t-distributed stochastic neighbor embedding (t-SNE), isometric mapping (Isomap), or locally linear embedding (LLE) for nonlinear structures [54]. Understanding data characteristics helps in selecting the appropriate dimensionality reduction method. Clustering in unsupervised learning groups objects so that those in the same cluster are more similar to each other than to those in different clusters [55]. The decision tree guides the choice of clustering algorithm based on data characteristics. If the number of clusters is unknown and a tree structure is needed, hierarchical clustering is suitable [56]. If the number of clusters (k) is predefined, k-means clustering is appropriate [57,58]. For identifying clusters of arbitrary shape and handling noise, density-based spatial clustering of applications with noise (DBSCAN) is ideal [59,60]. The decision tree helps determine whether to use hierarchical clustering, k-means, or DBSCAN based on whether the number of clusters needs to be specified and the nature of the data [61–64]. Regression, a supervised learning task, aims to predict a continuous numeric value based on input features [65]. The decision for regression starts by determining if a numeric prediction is required. If so, it proceeds to the regression methods; otherwise, it moves to classification methods [65]. The next step involves deciding whether to prioritize the model's accuracy or speed (rapidity). For high accuracy, consider complex models like random forest, which uses multiple decision trees to improve accuracy and control over-fitting [66]; gradient boosting tree, an ensemble technique that builds trees sequentially to correct previous errors [66]; or neural networks, which are highly flexible and capture complex data patterns [66,67]. While these models generally offer superior performance in supervised learning, linear regression and decision trees can still be effective in specific scenarios. For speed, simpler models like linear regression, which models the linear relationship between input features and the target variable [68], or decision tree, which split data based on feature values to make predictions, are recommended [69]. Random forest, gradient boosting tree, and neural network are slower and more computationally demanding than linear regression and decision tree due to their complexity [66,70–72]. These advanced models require extensive computation, memory, and processing power, whereas linear regression and decision tree are faster and less resource-intensive [68,73]. Algorithm speeds are commonly measured through execution time [74], computational power metric [75], rate-based model [76], and computation time [77]. Classification in supervised learning predicts categorical labels based on input features [78]. Decision-making involves first determining if categorical predictions are required. Classification methods are employed for tasks not needing numeric predictions. The flow chart compares various supervised learning algorithms used for classification, highlighting their relative strengths in terms of accuracy, interpretability, and suitability for different dataset sizes. Gradient boosting tree, random forests, and neural networks, positioned on the left, offer higher accuracy but are slower and less interpretable [79–81]. Determining the interpretability of an ML algorithm involves understanding its predictions and identifying the input features driving these predictions [82]. Techniques such as local interpretable model-agnostic explanations (LIME) and Shapley additive explanations (SHAP) are used to score and explain input features [83,84]. Neural networks, specifically, are best suited for large datasets [85]. Kernel SVMs also provides high accuracy but at the cost of speed and interpretability, fitting medium-sized datasets [86,87]. On the right, logistic regression and decision tree are noted for their strong interpretability and faster performance [88–90], while linear support vector classification (SVC) strikes a balance between speed, accuracy, and interpretability for medium-sized datasets [91,92]. The chart potentially guides the selection of a classification algorithm based on the specific needs and constraints of the data and the problem at hand. 3 Approach and impact of ML in HER catalyst synthesis The HER is a critical process in sustainable energy production, and significant research is being conducted on developing efficient and cost-effective catalysts for this reaction. Various catalysts and strategies are being explored, including heterostructured catalysts [93], mixed metal oxide electrocatalysts [94], and single-atom catalysts [95]. Each of these approaches offers unique advantages and potential for improving the efficiency and cost-effectiveness of HER catalysts. Density functional theory (DFT) is widely used to evaluate and predict the performance of HER catalysts, providing essential molecular knowledge for catalyst design and offering insights into the activity of various catalysts [96,97]. For example, DFT calculations can determine the Gibbs free energy of hydrogen adsorption (ΔG H*), which is a crucial parameter for assessing HER activity [9]. This molecular-level understanding helps anticipate viable catalysts and advance the development of electrocatalysts [98]. Despite its advantages, DFT has certain limitations. One significant challenge is that the HER activity is strongly related to the stability of the catalyst [17], setting practical limitations on their potential application in HER. Metallicity is the most important parameter for basal planes in determining activity rather than structure or composition. This indicates a limitation in making systematic improvements in activity without compromising stability [17]. Additionally, nudged elastic band calculations to suggest that HER may occur solely via the Volmer-Heyrovsky route for certain materials, highlighting a limitation in accurately predicting reaction mechanisms using DFT [17]. Furthermore, DFT calculations show that support interactions involving van der Waals forces can lead to significant changes in hydrogen binding energy, which affects HER activity [18]. This underlines a limitation in accurately predicting HER activity on supported catalysts. Integrating ML with DFT offers a promising solution to address these challenges. ML algorithms can complement DFT calculations by providing pivotal guidelines for experimental catalyst design and synthesis, such as using a fuzzy model for data separation and converse prediction of HER performance [99]. This hybrid approach leverages DFT's detailed molecular insights and ML's ability to process large datasets, identify patterns, and optimize catalyst performance more efficiently [32]. Consequently, it can significantly accelerate the discovery and development of high-performance HER catalysts, addressing the multifaceted challenges of current computational modeling practices. Utilizing information sourced from Scopus.com [100], Fig. 4 (a) illustrates the progression of exclusively research articles addressing themes associated with hydrogen production technologies, including the application of DFT and the combined use of DFT and MLs in synthesizing HER catalysts. The trend in the publication of research articles from 2000 to 2024 has shown repeated periods of steady increase and decrease, with a notable peak observed in 2021 for all types of studies, signaling the rise of ML in HER catalyst development. There is expected to be a continued steady increase in publications beyond 2024, given the time-consuming nature of modeling and simulation processes. It is also anticipated that the integration of ML and DFT will increase ahead of 2024, given the significant progress in DFT-based HER catalyst development over the past six years. As shown in Fig. 4(b), journal articles exploring ML in HER catalyst development have seen a noticeable rise from 2020 to 2024. 2023 saw the highest number of publications, particularly in ML applied to thermochemical-based catalysts. This trend might be motivated by the extensive data on the synthesis of thermochemical-based catalysts for conventional HPP methods such as steam methane reforming, pyrolysis, and gasification [32] ML-based HER electrocatalyst, photocatalyst/photoelectrode, and biocatalyst/bioelectrode development is projected to increase steadily in the future, driven by progressive studies on experimental and DFT-based HER catalyst synthesis, as seen in Fig. 4(a). Motivated by progressive effort in this field, this section will explore the approach, impact, challenges, and opportunities of integrating multiple ML algorithms and DFT in the development of HER catalysts, including thermochemical-based catalysts, electrocatalysts, photocatalysts/photoelectrodes, and biocatalysts/bioelectrode. 3.1 ML in thermochemical-based catalyst synthesis In steam methane reforming (SMR), a common process used to produce hydrogen gas, catalysts play a crucial role in facilitating the chemical reactions involved. The primary catalyst used in SMR is typically nickel-based. The role of the catalyst in SMR is to enhance the reaction rate and promote the desired chemical transformations. Specifically, the catalyst aids the conversion of methane and steam into carbon monoxide, and hydrogen gas through a series of reactions. Methane's importance as a greenhouse gas and industrial feedstock in the context of global warming and energy needs has spurred interest in its conversion through SMR [101,102], where Ni-based catalysts dominate despite their susceptibility to sintering and coking. Bimetallic materials show promise in catalysis owing to their highly active surface area [103,104], but are hindered by the complexity of metal combinations. DFT and surface dynamics offer valuable insights into catalyst systems [105], yet their computational demands limit their applicability [106]. To address this, the emergence of ML techniques has become increasingly valuable for material and catalyst development [107–109], utilizing vast datasets from experimental and theoretical sources. Two recent innovative research approaches exist for catalyst design and hydrogen production process modeling. The first approach involves a multiscale method that merges top-down and bottom-up strategies, utilizing microscopic descriptors and multiphysics modeling linked by an analytical model [110]. First-principles-based deep neural networks (DNNs) are employed to rapidly predict descriptors, aiding the search for efficient SMR catalysts. The study identifies three highly active, low-cost, and environmentally friendly catalysts—Ni3Ga, NiZn, and CoGa—by analyzing a database of bimetallic alloys. The second approach uses ML to model, design, and evaluate hydrogen production via the water–gas shift reaction (WGSR) [111]. The ML model predicts catalyst performance based on critical descriptors, enabling the kinetics-free simulation of HPP and evaluation of early-stage catalysts from an industrial perspective. Pt/Co (10 wt%)/Al2O3, Pt/Co (20 wt%)/Al2O3, and Pt/Ce (5 wt%)/TiO2 are identified as top-performing catalysts for high-purity hydrogen production. These methodologies represent promising advancements in catalyst development and hydrogen production optimization. Walker et al. [112] utilized a graph theory model as an alternative to DFT computations to generate descriptors for adsorption energy intermediates in the dry reforming of methane reactions. Although DFT was employed to compute some adsorbates, the graph theory model was used to predict the remaining adsorbates. ML is increasingly recognized for its potential in catalytic gasification processes, notably hydrothermal gasification (HTG), where catalysts play a critical role in enhancing hydrogen yield and selectivity while reducing energy requirements. While the literature on ML applications in this field is limited, recent studies have begun exploring its use, particularly in heterogeneous catalyst screening. Unified ML frameworks have been developed to predict syngas composition in supercritical water gasification (SCWG), aiding in catalyst screening and process optimization by identifying optimal conditions for maximizing hydrogen yield and minimizing CO2 yield. Recent ML advancements enable unified frameworks for optimizing catalytic gasification, exemplified by Li et al. [113]. Their ML framework predicts syngas composition in SCWG, aiding in catalyst screening and determining optimal conditions to maximize hydrogen yield and minimize CO2 yield. ML exploration identifies critical factors influencing syngas composition, guiding experimental design for improved process efficiency. Gopirajan et al. [114] developed an ML-based decision support system to optimize process conditions and biomass HTG product yield. Their approach analyses extensive datasets to establish correlations between biomass characteristics, process conditions, and product yield, guiding accurate predictions of HTG conditions based on biomass inputs. ML facilitates the identification of key factors for catalyst design and operational optimization in HTG. In thermochemical water splitting, high-temperature chemical reactions dissociate water into hydrogen and oxygen. ML approaches have been used in data analysis of DFT data to identify suitable dopants and establish important considerations for high hydrogen production. The exploration of appropriate dopants in ceria for thermochemical water splitting indicated that among 33 potential dopants, Y, Sc, Zr, Cr, Pd, and La are the most promising options [115]. Predictive models based on ML techniques, such as RF regression, have been used to assess the impacts of various attributes of perovskites on hydrogen production, with the band gap being an effective predictor [116]. In summary, the studies highlight the significance of catalysts in SMR and thermochemical water splitting for hydrogen production. Nickel-based catalysts dominate SMR despite challenges, and innovative approaches, including bimetallic materials and ML, show promise in identifying efficient catalysts such as Ni3Ga, NiZn, and Pt/Co (10 wt%)/Al2O3. ML proves instrumental in modeling and optimizing HPP, as demonstrated in the water–gas shift reaction (WGSR) and thermochemical water splitting. The future outlook suggests refining ML models, exploring advanced computational techniques, and deepening the understanding of catalyst-property relationships for sustainable energy advancements. Collaboration between experimental and theoretical methods and continued exploration of novel catalyst combinations are vital areas for further research and breakthroughs. Table S1 shows the analysis of the reviewed studies comparing the thermochemical-based HER catalyst materials, research objective, approach and impact of ML, and efficiency of selected studies. 3.2 ML in electrocatalyst synthesis Electrochemical reactions encompass two distinct half-reactions that take place at the anode and cathode, where the former involves processes such as oxygen evolution reaction (OER), and the latter encompasses reactions such as HER, oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), carbon dioxide reduction, or nitrogen reduction [117,118]. These reactions are driven by the transfer of electrons. The utilization of active catalysts becomes imperative to enhance efficiency and minimize the excess energy required (overpotential). Notably, the HER and ORR are pivotal in generating clean energy and finding widespread applications. The growing utilization of bimetallic or intermetallic materials, combinations of two or more metallic elements, is evident in catalysis, gas adsorption, electronics, and engineering, offering diverse properties due to their varied compositions, structures, and synergistic effects of mixed metals [119–121]. Advancing the design of intermetallic materials requires a comprehensive understanding of the relationships between composition and structure in this category. However, due to the high computational cost and complexity associated with accurately simulating intermetallic systems, current computational limitations hinder the extensive use of evolutionary algorithms and quantum–mechanical methods for customized intermetallic design. While ML training data often originate from computational methods, the efficiency of ML models in making predictions post-training offers a significant advantage. Unlike the computationally intensive nature of evolutionary algorithms and quantum–mechanical simulations, ML models can leverage pre-computed data to quickly and efficiently explore new intermetallic configurations [122]. Self-supervised pre-training models, which leverage expert knowledge and large datasets, offer more accurate predictions and can guide the discovery of new materials [122]. In this context, ML methods emerge as valuable predictive tools for intermetallic structures and properties [123]. For instance, Ryan et al. [124] developed a DNN model based on known crystal structures to predict compositions and structures of unknown intermetallics (Fig. 5 a). Using normalized atomic signatures as descriptors and focusing on structural topologies, the DNN model was trained with both positive and negative examples, estimating the probability of each element's location within specified structural template sites. Trained with 51,723 known crystal structure prototypes, the model successfully identified high-probability compositions and additional compositions within the LiMnGe ternary system, highlighting the efficacy of DNNs in exploring bimetallic and intermetallic materials without prior system knowledge. Efficient electrocatalytic water splitting relies on developing effective OER catalysts for enhancing HER efficiency [117,118]. Transition metal oxides, known for their structure–activity relationships, abundance, and cost-effectiveness, are promising, but efficient screening is needed due to the extensive oxide material space. ML, specifically symbolic regression, generates descriptors predicting quantitative OER activity in oxide perovskites [125–127]. The combination of tolerance factor (t) and octahedral factor (µ), µ/t, emerges as a key descriptor for the structural stability-OER activity relationship [125]. Using sure independence screening and sparsifying operator (SISSO), Xu et al. [128] identified critical characteristics predicting adsorption enthalpies of OH* and OOH* on transition metal-ion-doped IrO2 and RuO2 surfaces (Fig. 5b–d). Co and Fe were suggested as optimal dopants for enhancing OER activities, showcasing ML's potential to expedite the discovery of effective oxide electrocatalysts. A recent study developed a high-throughput screening method using DFT calculations and transfer learning to predict key properties of pyrochlore compounds [129]. Pyrochlore oxides, due to their versatile composition, show promise as acid OER catalysts. The screening identified 61 potential candidates out of 6912 compounds for acid OER applications. Additionally, p-block metals were considered beneficial additives to enhance catalytic activity alongside 3d-transition metals. To enhance efficiency and selectivity in metal catalysts, single-atom catalysts (SACs) are crucial, regulating and reducing metal particulate size on supports like metal oxides, metals, graphene, and porous frameworks [130,131]. SACs, isolating individual metal atoms, demonstrate optimal morphology, improving catalytic activity and selectivity. In HER and OER, SACs exhibit high reactivity and selectivity. ML and DFT expedite SAC development and offer insights into the relationship between features and activities [132]. Fung et al. [133] used SISSO to study transition metal SACs in N-doped graphene for HER, identifying key descriptors like covalent radius, d-state centers, electronegativity, number of occupied d states, and Bader charge. Additionally, 2D materials, known for large surface-to-volume ratios and excellent catalytic capabilities, are advantageous for energy applications. Transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDCs), popular HER catalysts [117], were explored by Ge et al. [134] using ML models. Trained with descriptors like rotational angle, bond length, layer spacing, and bandgap ratio, the models identified a MoTe2/WTe2 heterojunction with a 300° rotation angle as the most efficient electrocatalyst for HER. MXene, a class of 2D materials with the formula M n +1X n , where M is from group IIIB to VIB, X is carbon or nitrogen, and n ranges from 1 to 3, offers ample surface charges for easy functionalization [135]. Combining carbon/nitrogen atoms, transition metals, and diverse surface groups, MXene shows vast potential for optical, electronic, catalytic, and energy applications. Due to the diverse MXene landscape, ML is crucial for exploration. Wang et al. [136] used ML algorithms to link intrinsic properties of 2D MXene alloys to hydrogen adsorption energy, identifying descriptors predicting HER performance (Fig. 6 ). Zheng et al. [23] employed an RF model for screening 299 MXenes, identifying Os2B- and S-terminated materials as potential HER catalysts, emphasizing the importance of sulfur functional groups. These studies demonstrate the efficiency of ML in discovering MXene catalysts. Collectively, these studies emphasized the crucial significance of active catalysts, specifically those comprising bimetallic and intermetallic materials, in augmenting the efficacy of electrochemical reactions, including the HER and the OER. ML methods emerge as crucial tools for predicting unknown intermetallic compositions and optimizing the performance of transition metal oxides in the OER. The development of SACs and the exploration of 2D materials, including TMDCs and MXenes, further showcase the potential of ML in accelerating the discovery and design of efficient catalysts for energy applications. Table S2 summarizes the approaches and impacts of ML in synthesizing electrocatalysts with their efficiency prediction. 3.3 ML in photocatalyst/photoelectrode synthesis Photocatalysis and photoelectrochemical (PEC) water splitting have emerged as environmentally friendly and sustainable methods for hydrogen fuel production. The choice of semiconductor materials significantly impacts the solar-to-hydrogen conversion efficiency in PEC cells. Metal oxides, known for their exceptional PEC stability, cost-effectiveness, suitable band edge positions, and diverse bandgap distributions, have garnered considerable attention in developing nanomaterials for PEC water splitting [137–140]. TiO2, a widely used photocatalyst, presents challenges in understanding water adsorption on well-defined surfaces. Molecular dynamics simulations with an ab initio-based deep neural network (DNN) potential revealed a dynamic equilibrium between molecular and dissociative water adsorption on TiO2 [141]. Molecular water adsorption, with lower free energy (ΔF = 8.0 ± 0.9 kJ/mol) than dissociative adsorption, results in a 5.6% ± 0.5% equilibrium water dissociation fraction at room temperature. This model enhances comprehension of surface phenomena. In a related study, Iliuta et al. [142] used a neural network and genetic algorithm to optimize TiO2 photocatalysts for HER in a glycerol solution, yielding 321 μmol of hydrogen within 4 h. The utilization of ML models in perovskite photocatalyst design is still limited due to the scarcity of available data for model training and the lack of standardized characterization methods. To address this, Yildirim et al. [116] conducted a comprehensive data mining analysis, revealing trends in perovskite photocatalysis. Their results indicated that SrTiO3 stood out as the titanate most investigated, with a significant number of perovskites being doped at the A-site. The sol–gel synthesis method emerged as the most popular, and most studies incorporated cocatalysts. The collected data were used to train RF models for predicting HER and bandgap (Fig. 7 a–d). In a separate study, Tao et al. [143] employed ML models to screen over 30,000 perovskites, identifying fourteen oxide perovskites with desirable bandgaps range of (2.2–2.4 eV) and high HER (Fig. 7e). However, the limited size of the training dataset restricted the models' applicability. To enhance accuracy, standardized measurements and collaboration within the research community are essential for accumulating more data and improving ML models for perovskite analysis. Certain organic compounds, particularly conjugated polymers, display photocatalytic activity driven by their conjugated backbones and ionic-functionalized alkyl side chains. Despite their promise, the structure–property relationships of conjugated polymers remain unclear. Addressing this, Zwijnenburg et al. [144] employed a gradient boosting regression (GBR) model to analyze 6,354 conjugated copolymers and identify photocatalysts with high sacrificial HER. Effective catalysts require a combination of negative electron affinities, positive ionization energies, larger band gaps, and solvent dispersibility. In another approach, Yan et al. [145] used ML models to link experimental characteristics to element-doped graphitic carbon nitride (D-g-C3N4) for HER, accurately estimating hydrogen generation rates. Sensitivity analysis on input features revealed factors influencing photocatalytic performance, aiding in strategic elemental doping methods for g-C3N4 to enhance hydrogen production without expensive experiments. ML models have advanced our understanding of photocatalysis and water splitting for hydrogen production. They have gained insights into TiO2-water interfaces and perovskite photocatalysts, effectively screening materials and optimizing experimental conditions. Table S3 summarizes the approach, impact, and efficiency of ML in photocatalyst development. 3.4 ML in biocatalysts/bioelectrodes synthesis The research conducted by Wang et al. [146] employed an ML algorithm to examine the relationship between community data and electrochemical performance. To assess the impact of individual taxa within the microbial community on electrochemical performance, the genus-level microbial community compositions for each functional group were inputted into a andom forest algorithm, with current density data serving as the output feature. The study's findings underscored the significant role of Enterococcus spp. and highlighted the importance of specific bacterial species, particularly syntrophic fermentative bacteria, in determining current density [143]. This study represents a pioneering effort in utilizing ML to correlate microbial community analysis of bioanodes with bioelectrochemical performance, specifically in terms of current density for hydrogen production in microbial electrolysis cells (MEC). Future research endeavors should aim to expand upon these findings by investigating the correlation between microbial community composition and other performance parameters beyond current density. For instance, employing ML to study biofilm formation on different materials could yield valuable insights into enhancing bioanode development. 3.5 Insight, challenges, and opportunities of ML in HER catalyst synthesis Integrating ML with DFT and other computational modeling and optimization techniques revolutionizes catalyst design, optimization, and material discovery across various energy-related applications. ML methods are employed to rapidly analyze vast datasets, aiding in identifying efficient catalysts and optimizing reaction conditions. Multiscale modeling approaches, combining microscopic descriptors and multiphysics modeling, leverage ML to accelerate catalyst screening and identify environmentally friendly catalysts. ML plays a pivotal role in modeling thermochemical processes, such as hydrothermal gasification and water splitting, enabling the prediction of syngas composition and process optimization. Moreover, ML techniques expedite the discovery and design of efficient catalysts, including bimetallic and intermetallic materials, single-atom catalysts, and 2D materials, by predicting unknown compositions and optimizing material properties for various electrochemical reactions. In photocatalysis and PEC water splitting, ML aids in understanding surface phenomena, screening semiconductor materials, and optimizing experimental conditions for efficient hydrogen production. Further investigation is required to establish a correlation between microbial community analysis of bioanodes and bioelectrochemical performance by employing ML techniques. This necessity arises due to the expanding dataset of microbial community analysis within the bioelectrochemical research domain to support the correlation. Despite significant headway, constructing accurate and widely applicable ML models encounters hurdles, chiefly requiring extensive and high-quality datasets. Acquiring such datasets poses difficulties due to experimental parameters' sensitivity and the absence of standardized metadata in published literature, making results incomparable. Leonard et al. [147] proposed that researchers using the CataLST cycle can contribute to building an 'Internet of Catalysis' (IoC). The IoC could electronically archive experiment data, analyze it, and guide the development of new catalysts and processes by identifying specific molecular constructs or conditions for desired reactions. Catalytic processes exhibit high sensitivity to experimental parameters and often overlooked conditions, adding complexity to modeling efforts. Concerns about the reliability of published data, including unexpected outcomes such as hydrogen generation from sacrificial reagent oxidation [148], highlight the need for rigorous scrutiny. Reproducibility challenges in experimental results under identical conditions emphasize the importance of catalyst experts' critical analysis before integrating data into ML training sets. Additionally, the potential bias in ML models, stemming from the tendency to report only successful results, underlines the necessity for an inclusive approach in dataset curation to ensure unbiased and effective models capturing diverse catalytic behaviors. To address this, enhanced collaboration between data scientists, materials scientists, and catalyst experts, along with adopting high-throughput methods, emerges as a potential solution to improve data reliability and comparability. Furthermore, the scarcity of experimental or first-principles computational data is another challenge, prompting the exploration of reinforcement, active, transfer learning, and meta-learning techniques. Meta-learning, in particular, holds promise by enabling models to adapt and generalize based on experiences from other models trained on larger datasets [149]. For example, a new method utilizing stepwise consensus and a stacking meta-learning algorithm may reliably predict bandgaps and HER of photocatalysts [150]. Utilizing smaller datasets for training, these models effectively screen through more than 10 million materials, discerning compounds with potential and non-toxic attributes suitable for photocatalytic water splitting (PWS). Transformational ML (TML) is also considered a viable solution for dealing with small datasets [151]. TML occurs when various ML problems (tasks) are interconnected. In this scenario, the features can be transformed into external features. This is achieved by initially training ML models on different tasks, allowing them to predict outcomes for each example in the new task. This process results in the creation of a unique representation. This approach shows the potential acceleration of research in thermocatalytic, electrocatalytic, photocatalytic, and biocatalytic materials. While successful in structure-electro/photoactivity modeling, there is a notable gap in applying ML to kinetic studies of electro/photocatalytic reactions. For instance, ML has been applied to ultrafast proton-coupled electron transfer (PCET) studies [152]. However, its broader application to various kinetic processes faces challenges in probing excited states and lacks sufficient data for model training. Advances in experimental technologies, like Kelvin probe force microscopy and transient spectroscopy, address these challenges and contribute to studying carrier mobility. ML techniques also enhance the efficiency and accuracy of time-dependent DFT calculations for exploring electron dynamics in the excited states of photocatalysts [153]. The combination of cutting-edge experimental technologies and ML, especially with in situ investigation data and molecular dynamic simulations, is expected to contribute to this field significantly. Another significant challenge in the field lies in describing complex catalytic mechanisms using simple and interpretable descriptors. These descriptors are pivotal in shaping the quality of ML models by connecting catalyst features to dynamic events in catalysis. Descriptor selection involves various strategies, including relying on chemical and physical intuition, using algorithms like principal component analysis (PCA), multiple linear regression with expectation maximization (MLREM), and least absolute shrinkage and selection operator (LASSO), or employing algorithms to prune descriptors (e.g., tree models, regularization) [154]. Innovations like generative neural networks (NNs), symbolic learning, and sure independence screening and sparsifying operator (SISSO) contribute to generating informative descriptors from a potential pool [155]. Markedly, developing computable, efficient, and interpretable material descriptors, mainly through deep learning (DL) algorithms, is a crucial research need. Although DL lacks interpretability compared to traditional ML due to its complexity [156,157], techniques like local interpretation methods [158], visualization, model distillation, activation maximization, and attribution [159], as well as model transformation [160], have been developed to address the issue. Additionally, post-hoc interpretability methods provide explanations after training, maintaining model performance [161]. These approaches enhance the transparency and applicability of DL models in real-world scenarios by providing explanations for predictions and maintaining model performance. Furthermore, DL algorithms like convolutional neural nets (CNN), generative adversarial networks (GANs), and encoder-decoder networks show promise in generating latent descriptors from simple representations[162–165]. These advancements are anticipated to improve the efficacy of ML models in suggesting molecules or materials with superior properties. To recap, the employment of ML in catalysis highlights progress and challenges. Obtaining high-quality datasets remains a key obstacle addressed by the proposed 'Internet of Catalysis' (IoC) for electronic archiving. Collaboration and high-throughput methods are suggested to enhance dataset reliability. Challenges persist in limited experimental and computational data, prompting exploration of meta-learning and transformational TML. While structure–activity modeling has succeeded, a gap exists in ML for kinetic studies, with recent advancements poised to fill this void. Descriptors for catalytic mechanisms are challenging, emphasizing the need for efficient, interpretable material descriptors through DL. Advancements in convolutional neural nets and generative adversarial networks are anticipated to boost ML models' efficacy in suggesting superior molecules or materials. An illustration of the summarized challenges and opportunities of ML-based catalyst development is presented in Fig. 8 . 4 Approach and impact of ML in hydrogen production processes (HPP) Optimizing HPP is vital for meeting rising demand, ensuring economic and environmental sustainability, improving efficiency, and advancing technology. Challenges in this field include diverse production methods such as water electrolysis, steam methane reforming, and biomass gasification, each with unique modeling needs. The complexity of these processes, including reforming reactions, membrane reactors, and chemical looping, further complicates accurate modeling [166–169]. Energy efficiency and cost considerations are crucial, requiring models that address multi-period optimization and economic assessments [170–172]. Additionally, developing new materials and technologies, such as proton exchange membrane water electrolysis (PEMWE), necessitates advanced modeling techniques for enhanced efficiency and reliability [172,173]. Conventional computational models for hydrogen production often lack the necessary physical detail, leading to inaccurate predictions of energy efficiency and separation performance [167,170]. This inadequacy is compounded using unreasonable unit models that inadequately represent hydrogen users and producers, with fixed throughputs and constant feed concentrations hindering comprehensive design considerations [171]. Moreover, conventional models struggle to depict the dynamic, non-linear interactions in biohydrogen processes accurately [174]. Additionally, current process simulation platforms fall short in effectively simulating chemical looping processes for hydrogen production, restricting optimization efforts to reactor size and process design [175]. These limitations highlight the need for more advanced and detailed modeling approaches to improve the accuracy and efficacy of hydrogen production simulations. The advancement of computational engineering, digitalization, and ML offers promising solutions to these limitations. Data-driven models such as the widely known random forest (RF), support vector machines (SVM), gradient boosting machine (GBM), and artificial neural networks (ANNs) can provide rapid, cost-effective, and accurate modeling, identifying patterns, and optimizing processes beyond the capabilities of traditional methods [176–178]. By integrating ML or multiple ML algorithms with conventional computational methods and establishing hybrid optimization of HPP, the hydrogen production industry can significantly improve efficiency, cost-effectiveness, and sustainability. This approach effectively addresses the multifaceted challenges of current modeling practices. The volume of published papers employing a hybridized strategy of optimization tools or computational modeling (Opt/CM) and ML in HPP peaked in 2023, surpassing those solely utilizing ML techniques (Fig. 9 a). This trend showcases the effectiveness and reliability of the hybridization approach of Opt/CM and ML over the past five years (2020–2024). Fig. 9(b) illustrates the publication trend on using ML in various HPP technologies acquired from the Scopus database [100]. Notably, the use of ML in HPP has seen active research since 2020, peaking in 2023. Photonic-based HPP showed the highest publication numbers in 2022 and 2023, aligning with the green energy movement. A continuous rise in the application of ML for optimizing various HPPs is anticipated, fueled by ongoing advancements in optimization and computational modeling in HPPs, as illustrated in Fig. 9(a). 4.1 ML in thermochemical-based hydrogen production processes Owing to the numerous hydrogen production technologies, this section's classification of thermochemical-based processes is exclusively for ML-based HPP, including steam methane reforming (SMR), gasification, and thermochemical water-splitting. The SMR process is a widely used and economically viable method for hydrogen production. It utilizes natural gas and steam over a nickel catalyst, with methane undergoing reforming between 700 and 1000 °C and 3 to 25 bar pressure [179]. The process consists of two stages: first, methane decomposes into hydrogen and carbon monoxide, and then the “water-gas shift reaction” occurs, leading to the formation of carbon dioxide and additional hydrogen [180]. Several recent studies have explored the application of ML in optimizing SMR processes for hydrogen production. Nkulikiyinka et al. [181] focused on sorption-enhanced SMR, employing ANN and RF models to estimate hydrogen and carbon dioxide synthesis utilizing sensor measurements of steam-to-carbon ratio, sorbent-to-carbon ratio, converter pressure, and temperatures, the ANN model demonstrated high accuracy in estimating H2 production, with an R 2 of 0.98, RMSE of 0.02, and MAE of 0.016, while the RF model also performed well. In a separate investigation, an ANN based on 485,710 operational datasets optimized the SMR process for hydrogen production, achieving high accuracy with an average R 2 of 0.9987 [182]. The model accurately predicted syngas flow rate, carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide, methane, hydrogen compositions, and steam temperature, leading to process optimization and a resulting thermal efficiency of 85.6%. Gasification offers potential for renewable energy generation from waste, particularly in hydrogen production and power generation through coal and biomass gasification. In biomass gasification, integrating multiple MLs predicts critical gasification outputs like carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide, methane, hydrogen, and HHV [183]. Various ML methods forecast carbon conversion, hydrogen, and carbon monoxide yields, identifying optimal conditions for maximum syngas and hydrogen production. For instance, operating at 900 °C for the first stage and 1000 °C for the second stage, with a steam/carbon ratio of 3.8, resulted in the highest syngas (96.2 wt%) and hydrogen (70 mol%) yields [184]. ML approaches, especially the RF model, outperformed Gaussian process regression, ANN, and SVM models in predicting hydrogen production from biomass (SCWG) [185]. Hybrid models, such as integrating particle swarm optimization (PSO) and ANN, namely feed-forward backpropagation and cascade forward propagation, demonstrated improved modeling precision [186], showcasing the potential of such models for robust predictions in biomass gasification. Thermochemical water splitting (TCWS) shows promise for sustainable hydrogen production [187,188] through heat-induced reactions [187]. While research extensively explores catalytic reactions and thermodynamics, implementing TCWS in industries faces challenges in optimizing multiple design objectives [189–191]. Li et al. [192] applied genetic algorithms to optimize heat transfer processes in the nuclear-based Cu-Cl cycle, addressing fault detection and multi-objective optimization. Ahmet et al. [193,194] considered various scenarios, including single-objective and two-objective cases, focusing on factors such as exergy efficiency, total cost, and environmental impact rate. Ozcan and Dincer [195]extended this to a four-step Mg-Cl cycle, achieving improved efficacy and reduced costs with the genetic algorithm (GA). Nevertheless, a literature gap exists in optimizing a lab-scale facility for the Cu-Cl cycle. Farsi et al. [177] filled a literature gap by optimizing a lab-scale Cu-Cl cycle for hydrogen production using ANN, ML, and a multi-objective genetic algorithm (MOGA). The study revealed that increasing specific temperatures and the St/Cu molar ratio improves exergy efficiency, lower operational costs, and raises hydrogen production costs, showing a trade-off. Higher thermolysis and electrolyzer temperatures enhance efficiency and reduce costs with no conflict between objectives (Fig. 10 ). El Jery et al. [196] addressed another gap, integrating energy and exergy analyses with solar concentrating systems for polymer membrane electrolyzers, achieving exceptional predictive modeling with ANN. The studies stress the pivotal role of ML in optimizing HPP, such as SMR, gasification, and TCWS. ML techniques like ANN, RF, and GA are adept at accurately predicting key parameters and optimizing process conditions, leading to enhanced efficiency and sustainability. Importantly, ML-based approaches outperform traditional modeling techniques, particularly in complex processes like biomass gasification and TCWS, and facilitate multi-objective optimization, considering factors like exergy efficiency and environmental impact. Table S4 presents a detailed performance of ML-based thermochemical HPP of selected studies. 4.2 ML in HPP via electrical (electrolysis) Hydrogen production via water electrolysis, utilizing technologies such as alkaline water electrolysis (AWE), proton exchange membrane water electrolyzer (PEMWEs), anion exchange membrane water electrolyzer (AEMWEs), and solid oxide water electrolyzer (SOWEs), holds significant promise in enhancing energy utilization efficiency, particularly in light of the unpredictable nature of renewable power sources [197]. Recent research highlights the crucial role of ML techniques in optimizing the performance and design of AWE [198], PEMWE [199], AEM [200], and SOWE [201] systems. By employing ML models, precise electrolysis power, cooling requirements, and temperature maintenance calculations can be achieved, ultimately leading to cost-effective operations. Shangguan et al. [198] analyzed AWE for hydrogen production, focusing on various aspects such as thermal balance, operating conditions, efficiency, and lifecycle cost. They developed and improved a thermal balance model using ML techniques based on experimental data. This model accurately calculated electrolysis power, cooling needs, and temperature maintenance, enabling cost-effective operation. Their study offers valuable insights for optimizing AWE performance and economic feasibility in hydrogen production. For PEMWE, Mohamed et al. [199] utilized multiple ML models, including polynomial and logistic regression, to predict the optimal design of PEMWE. Their approach demonstrated high accuracy and low error rates through training on a dataset of 148 samples. Experimental validation confirmed the practical applicability of ML models in designing optimal cells for commercial-scale hydrogen production. Similarly, Yang et al. [202] proposed an ML-based approach for selecting optimal design factors for PEMWE, including flow-path design. Multiple ML models showcased exceptional reliability, accurately predicting crucial parameters for commercial-scale hydrogen production rates. Additionally, a database for PEM and AEM electrolyzers for hydrogen production has been developed using novel techniques such as local interpretable model-agnostic explanations (LIME), neural network pattern recognition (NNPR), and association rule mining (ARM) [200]. LIME helped uncover rules leading to high current density, low power density, and low polarization, while ARM provided dominant rules leading to high current density. Furthermore, LIME and NN pattern recognition highlighted the importance of various factors like operational variables, membrane types, catalytic materials, and gas diffusion layers on current density. Renewable energy sources (RES), including solar, wind, hydropower, biomass, geothermal, and tidal energy, are gaining prominence for their sustainability and low environmental impact. Integrating these sources into energy systems is crucial for addressing energy challenges, but their intermittent nature poses data handling difficulties. Developing effective technology for storing renewable energy is essential as various methods for supplying electrical energy from these sources emerge [203]. Energy monitoring and forecasting, employing ML models, are crucial in optimizing systems and policymaking, focusing on accuracy and efficiency [204]. One study assessed hydrogen production in a PEMWE supported by GaAs photovoltaic technology, employing various ML models such as ANN, DL, adaptive network fuzzy inference system (ANFIS), multiple linear regression (MLR), and ensemble averaging perceptron (EAP) to predict daily radiation values. The DL model demonstrated the highest compatibility, achieving a performance value of 96.26% (R 2) [205]. Salari et al. [206] investigated an integrated photovoltaic thermal system with proton exchange membrane methanol electrolyzer (PEMME) and PEMWE for hydrogen production, utilizing ANN to assess the impact of operating parameters. To optimize system performance, they applied the multi-objective whale optimization algorithm (MOWOA) and the multi-objective bat algorithm (MOBA) (Fig. 11 ). The study found that, under the same conditions, the water-based PVT system produced more electrical and thermal output than the water/methanol-based PVT system. However, the PVT-PEMME system surpassed the PVT-PEMWE system in hydrogen production efficiency, attributed to the higher efficiency of the PEMME. Javaid et al. [207] explored the feasibility of using wind energy for hydrogen production in a suburban environment, employing AI techniques, including long short-term memory (LSTM), support vector regression (SVR), and linear regression. LSTM exhibited the best prediction performance, estimating an average of 6.76 kg/day of hydrogen production from a 1.5 MW wind turbine. Another proposal introduced a wind-pumped storage-hydrogen storage combined operation system, utilizing DL and intelligent optimization [208]. DNN predicted wind power and a genetic algorithm optimized parameter, reducing daily power fluctuation by 77.60%, yielding a daily economic benefit of 19.7 K USD. Finally, a novel integrated system utilized geothermal energy for hydrogen production and liquefaction, optimizing hydrogen production rate (154.95 kg/h), total cost rate (291.36 $/h), and exergy efficiency (23.34%) through multi-objective optimization combining ANN with a genetic algorithm [209]. Turning our attention to SOWE, Sun et al. [201] optimized solid oxide co-electrolysis with renewable power using multi-physics simulation and DL algorithm. Their model shows a small error (<1%) and considers factors like reactions and heat transfer. Different optimization goals are assessed, focusing on reactant conversion and energy efficiency at various temperatures. Electrolysis efficiency decreases as the power supply increases. At different temperatures, a balanced thermal condition is reached with specific power ranges. In summary, recent studies have advanced hydrogen production technologies by integrating ML techniques to optimize the performance and design of AWE and PEMWEs, AEMWE, and SOWE (Table S5). Innovative methods such as LIME, NNPR, and ARM have identified crucial electrolyzer performance factors. Additionally, the increasing use of RES indicates the importance of ML-based energy monitoring and forecasting for system optimization. While significant progress has been made in utilizing ML for AWE and PEMWE, a literature survey indicates a gap in ML-based optimization for AEMWE and SOWE. This presents an opportunity to enhance technology efficiency through ML optimization. 4.3 ML in HPP via photonic reaction Efforts to enhance the energy conversion efficiency of photocatalytic hydrogen evolution from solar energy have been focused on optimizing operational parameters and chemical reaction kinetics. Despite existing studies in energy engineering [210–212], uncertainty persists in optimizing operational parameters when a photocatalyst is loaded into the reactor, influencing hydrogen yield and solar-to-hydrogen conversion efficiency. Introducing a novel optimization model based on partial differential equations (PDE), this approach utilizes Sobol's method and Gaussian process regression (GPR) to coordinate reaction mechanisms and operational parameters [176]. This effectively reduces computational complexity and enhances solar-to-hydrogen conversion efficiency. The validated mathematical model investigates hydrogen yield under varied conditions, employing a memetic algorithm that combines whale optimization and simulated annealing to identify optimal solutions. Another study explores multiple ML techniques, including scaled conjugate gradient descent neural networks (SCDNN), Levenberg–Marquardt neural networks (LMNN), and SVM, comparing them with response surface model (RSM) and nonlinear regression model (NLM) [213]. The objective is to model photocatalytic hydrogen production from ethanol using copper oxide (CuO) nanoparticles as the photocatalyst. LMNN exhibits superior predictive performance, with sensitivity analysis highlighting the significant influence of irradiation time on predicted hydrogen production [122]. Ren et al. [214] aimed to optimize the compound parabolic collector (CPC) structure and the operating conditions of the photoreactor. Their bi-level optimization model, incorporating PDE constraints, utilized the Sobol method and an extreme learning machine (ELM) surrogate model to achieve higher energy conversion efficiency than unoptimized systems. This study effectively synergizes the CPC and photoreactor components by integrating advanced optimization techniques, ML, and energy conversion mechanisms (Fig. 12 a and b). The study demonstrated that advanced optimization techniques and ML could effectively enhance the synergy between the CPC and photoreactor components. The new method reduced the number of function evaluations and computational costs, identifying optimal CPC structures and operating parameters, thus improving conversion efficiency. This research offers valuable insights into optimizing CPC structures and photoreactor operations to boost energy conversion efficiency. In the pursuit of efficient hydrogen production, photoelectrochemical (PEC) processes present a promising alternative to utilizing water [138,215,216]. Researchers actively employ ML techniques to enhance PEC hydrogen production efficiency [217,218]. Oral et al. [217] utilized various ML techniques to examine a dataset comprising 10,560 data points from 584 experiments related to n-type semiconductors for PEC water splitting. Techniques such as association rule mining (ARM), decision tree (DT), and RF were employed to reveal patterns in the correlation between photocurrent density and 33 descriptors. Notably, ARM identified significant factors influencing both photocurrent density and band gap. The DT model showed high accuracy for band gap (78% training, 72% testing) and, though slightly less accurate, still notable for photocurrent density (61% training, 54% testing). The RF model accurately predicted the electrode band gap with low RMSE (0.24 for validation, 0.27 for testing). Hogerwaard et al. [218] introduced a solar concentration system with a combined PEC reactor under simulated and natural solar light conditions (Fig. 12c). This innovative system, incorporating spectrum-splitting, achieves notable energy and exergy efficiencies of 71.5% and 69.7%, respectively. Integrating concentrated photovoltaic (CPV) with PEC demonstrates overall energy and exergy efficiencies of 1.7% and 1.3%, highlighting primary losses in transmission, light concentration, and reflection. Using parametric study data, a model was developed and optimized with neural networks and a genetic algorithm. This optimization significantly improved the PV system's power and efficiency, achieving a maximum PV power of 9.87 W, PV energy efficiency of 8.5%, and concentrator efficiency of 0.19%. The model's accuracy and the identification of a single global optimum indicate its effectiveness in optimizing the system. Research strives to improve the efficiency of photocatalytic hydrogen production from solar energy. Past studies optimized parameters and reactions, introducing a novel PDE-based model for industrial photocatalytic technology. Further investigations concentrate on ML techniques for modeling hydrogen production from ethanol and optimizing PEC processes for efficient water-based hydrogen production. Like Levenberg–Marquardt neural networks, ML techniques display superior predictive performance. In essence, the importance of ML and advanced optimization techniques in advancing hydrogen production technologies is emphasized. The research objective, approach, and impact of ML in photonic-based HPP of selected studies are tabulated in Table S6. 4.4 ML in HPP via a biochemical reaction Biohydrogen is a form of renewable energy that can be produced through biological processes using microorganisms. The process involves converting organic materials, such as biomass or organic waste, into hydrogen through biological reactions. Different techniques, such as dark fermentation (DF), photofermentation (PF), and microbial electrolysis cells (MEC), can accomplish this. DF is increasingly recognized as a sustainable method for biohydrogen production, offering advantages such as consuming diverse substrates, operating without light, and utilizing a cost-effective reactor setup under ambient conditions [219–221]. Despite its potential, the performance of the DF process is affected by factors such as substrate, pH, process type, temperature, and hydraulic retention time (HRT), influencing metabolite outcomes [222]. A combination of experimental and numerical approaches is essential to optimize DF. Recent research by Hosseinzadeh et al. [223] utilized ML techniques to model hydrogen production from wastewater during DF, evaluating models such as RF, GBM, AdaBoost, and SVM. Optimized through grid search, these ML models demonstrated robust performance with high determination coefficients (R 2) and low mean squared error (MSE) values. Notably, RF-permutation variable importance (PVI) analysis highlighted the significance of variables like ethanol, Fe, Ni, acetate, butyrate, and acetate/butyrate ratio in influencing the DF process, providing valuable insights into optimizing biohydrogen production. Investigations into harnessing biohydrogen from microalgae through the PF process are gaining attraction as a viable alternative energy source. The complexity of biological processes, such as photosynthetic mechanisms and metabolic pathways, poses challenges for traditional modeling and optimization techniques. ML algorithms have emerged as valuable tools to overcome these limitations, enabling accurate and efficient analysis by predicting nonlinear interactions and handling multivariate data. The SVM has found widespread application in detecting and diagnosing faults in biochemical and chemical processes, achieving flawless 100% diagnosis performance in scenarios with specified light-intensity operating ranges [224]. However, when pH values deviated, the diagnosis performance experienced a delay of 55%. In parallel, ANN approaches optimized hydrogen production in immobilized photobacteria and predicted favorable conditions for microalgal biohydrogen production [225]. In a different study, the ANFIS, a variant of ANN, outperformed traditional analysis of variance (ANOVA) by generating hydrogen from microalgal fermentation (200 mL/L), highlighting the superior predictive capabilities of ML in such studies [226]. MECs present a challenge for accurate modeling due to their nonlinear and complex nature arising from intricate biochemical network interactions. Sewsynker et al. [227] tackled this challenge by employing a committee of five ANNs to model the biohydrogen yield in MECs. The inputs encompassed pH, temperature, substrate type, concentration, reactor design, and applied voltage, derived from 50 data points across 15 studies. The committee model demonstrated R 2 values ranging from 0.70 to 0.90, showing a strong correlation between predicted and observed hydrogen yields. Sensitivity analysis identified substrate type as the most impactful parameter, followed by substrate concentration, applied voltage, MEC configuration, temperature, and pH. This study highlighted the committee model's effectiveness in capturing nonlinear relationships, aiding MEC scale-up optimization. Combining MECs with anaerobic digestion (AD), known as MEC-AD or electro-methanogenesis, improves methane production yield, productivity, and waste treatment performance compared to standalone AD processes [228,229]. Despite the literature's scarcity of MEC-AD models, Nguyen et al. [146] propose the effective use of AI techniques, particularly ANNs, for modeling and optimizing MEC-AD. In MEC-AD with alkaline-pretreated sludge, a high-performing ANN (2–25–34–6 topology) demonstrated strong predictability (low MSE of 0.0579, high R-value of 0.987). It enhances energy output and economic value (up to 160% and 300%, respectively) compared to AD alone at 0.63 V. However, additional research is essential for assessing stability under continuous operation, optimizing various parameters, and conducting a thorough economic analysis for industrial-scale MEC-AD applications.
